encodingDesc.projectDesc: The project focuses on digitising oral folktales from Ghana, specifically the Konkomba people, through different media. The project puts a body of oral folktales into writing and eventually makes them available as annotated, digitised narratives. It thus aims to make a contribution to visibilising this culture, which through processes of colonisation, the accompanying priviledging of written/print culture and Eurocentric/Western thinking has been marginalised.

body.head: The Crocodile Steals 10 Sisters' Waist Beads
body.p:
(As told by Uninkpel Gmasimboon at Chakping on 16/03/2022)
Introduction
The story below relates an encounter between ten sisters and a crocodile, which eventually results in the death of one of them. The story has it that the sisters go to bath at the river. Unfortunately, the crocodile confiscates their waist beads and eats one of them. The story is an etiological tale that seeks to explain why crocodiles attack and even eat human beings, but it fails woefully at that – to say the least. That said, it poses questions as regards the operations of fate. For example, was the last sister simply unlucky or a victim of fate?
Story
There lived a woman who had ten children – they were all girls, Gmasimboon commences his rendition without the usual protocol of announcing his intent to tell his story.
One day the girls went to take their baths at the riverside. On arrival, they took off their ileen and started bathing. As the sisters were bathing, ukpindaan came out of the river, took their ileen and returned into the water with them.
Soon, the girls were done bathing and wanted to return home. But where were their ileen? The eldest of the girls broke into song:

Note
1.
Binaanum are one of the neighbours of the Konkomba people while Bijingbeeb are Muslim merchants with whom Konkombas have often traded. In this story, the two are deliberately labelled as “passers-by” to draw attention to their status as visitors or traders on the move. It might be of interest to know that the word ‘Binaanum’ is the Likpakpaln name for the Nanumba people of northern Ghana while Bijingbeeb is the Likpakpaln name for the Hausa people. Even though there are standardised names – usually Anglicised forms – for the various ethnic groups in Ghana, the ethnic groups have their own local versions/vernacular names for themselves and for the other ethnic groups. For instance, Konkombas call themselves Bikpakpaam and refer to their neighbours (i.e., the Nanumba people) as Binaanum. The latter in turn call the Konkomba people Kpankpaamba instead of the Anglicised form, Konkomba.
A Glossary of Likpakpaln Words
Asantes:
plural form of Asante. The Asante people, who are commonly known as Ashanti people or Ashantis, are one of the ethnic groups in Ghana that make up the Akan group. They inhabit the southern part of Ghana, especially the Ashanti region. Hausa:
plural form of Hausa. The Hausa people inhabit various countries across West and Central Africa. liwakpil (aka liwakpol/liwankpol):
literally translated variously as a dead thing, carcass or dysfunctional thing, it a derogatory word often used by Konkombas to denigrate something as ugly, undesirable or substandard. Note that during articulation, the “n” in liwankpol is silent in some Likpakpaln dialects. Similarly, liwakpil is articulated with an “n” in some Likpakpaln dialects. Nanumbas:
plural form of Nanumba (i.e., the Nanumba ethnic group). unyanyaan:
Likpakpaln word for someone or something beautiful, attractive, nice or appealing. In the context of this story, it refers to the physically attractive child. In another context, it can also refer to something or someone with good inner qualities than just physical looks.
